title: How to Clean Mold from Grout

steps.title: Apply warm water.
steps.content: Apply warm water. Fill a bucket or spray bottle with warm water. Douse small sections of grout at a time. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the grout in a vigorous, back-and-forth motion.
steps.content: Scrub the grout in a vigorous, back-and-forth motion. Use a narrow scrub brush, tile brush, or stiff toothbrush. [2] X Research source If you’re having trouble getting into corners or grout lines with your brush, try using a Mr. Clean Magic Eraser for those areas. [3] X Research source Instead of a scrub brush, you can try a closed-loop microfiber cloth. If so, wear gloves to protect your hands from the friction.

steps.title: Try a baking soda paste.
steps.content: Try a baking soda paste. If water alone doesn’t work, mix three parts baking soda with one part water to form a paste. [4] X Expert Source Chris Willatt House Cleaning Professional Expert Interview. 1 July 2019. Apply the paste to the grout, and let it sit for one to two hours. Spray with plain water, then scrub the grout again. [5] X Research source Alternately, make a paste from two parts baking soda to one part hydrogen peroxide. Let the paste sit on the grout for several minutes before scrubbing it and rinsing it clean.

steps.title: Rinse the grout with water.
steps.content: Rinse the grout with water. Use clean running water, a spray bottle or a clean, wet sponge to rinse the grout.

steps.title: Dry the grout.
steps.content: Dry the grout. Use clean cloths to buff remaining moisture from the grout. Open a window or turn on a fan until the grout is dry to the touch. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Ensure proper safety and ventilation.
steps.content: Ensure proper safety and ventilation. Open the window and/or run a fan. Wear non-porous gloves, a mask, and safety glasses. Chlorine bleach is an eye and skin irritant. The fumes can affect the respiratory tract. Adequate protection and ventilation are essential. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Make a diluted bleach solution.
steps.content: Make a diluted bleach solution. Mix three parts water to one part chlorine bleach. Alternately, you can purchase a cleaning solution that contains some bleach. [8] X Research source If your grout is colored, using bleach may cause it to fade, especially if used regularly. You can repeat this method with a slightly higher concentration of bleach (for example, half bleach, half water) if the 3-to-1 ratio doesn’t work. Never attempt to mix other chemicals with diluted bleach. For example, ammonia – found in many cleaning agents – emits toxic fumes when mixed with bleach.

steps.title: Wet tiles with water.
steps.content: Wet tiles with water. Thoroughly wet any tiles in the area with warm water before using any bleach solution. Even if you’re just cleaning the grout, spatter will land on tiling. Pre-wetting tiles with water saturates them to limit their absorption of chemicals. [9] X Trustworthy Source US National Park Service Agency responsible for the maintenance and promotion of national parks and monuments Go to source

steps.title: Apply the bleach solution.
steps.content: Apply the bleach solution. Use a narrow brush such as an old, stiff toothbrush or any natural bristle or nylon brush. Scrub the grout with the solution in small sections. [10] X Trustworthy Source US National Park Service Agency responsible for the maintenance and promotion of national parks and monuments Go to source Bleach can lighten mold so that it isn’t visible. Scrubbing is needed to reach into grout’s pores and remove organic growth. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Soak and rinse the grout.
steps.content: Soak and rinse the grout. Let the solution remain on each section of grout for about three minutes. Then rinse it clean with clear water. [12] X Trustworthy Source US National Park Service Agency responsible for the maintenance and promotion of national parks and monuments Go to source Letting bleach sit for more than a few minutes can cause staining, streaking, or even breakage to tile.

steps.title: Dry the grout.
steps.content: Dry the grout. Buff away any remaining moisture with clean cloths. Leave the window open or fan running until the grout feels totally dry.

steps.title: Spray the grout with diluted vinegar.
steps.content: Spray the grout with diluted vinegar. Fill a bucket or spray bottle with one part water to one part white vinegar. Leave the solution on the grout for five minutes. Scrub the grout with a narrow scrub brush or stiff toothbrush. Rinse the area clean with warm water. [13] X Expert Source Chris Willatt House Cleaning Professional Expert Interview. 1 July 2019. Vinegar is acid-based, so make sure to do a small test area first to make sure the solution doesn’t affect your surrounding tile. Optionally, apply a paste of baking soda and water to the grout before dousing it with the vinegar solution. The combination will bubble up. Then scrub and rinse. [14] X Expert Source Chris Willatt House Cleaning Professional Expert Interview. 1 July 2019.

steps.title: Treat the grout with hydrogen peroxide.
steps.content: Treat the grout with hydrogen peroxide. Make sure to do a small test area first. Use a spray bottle or sponge to apply hydrogen peroxide to your grout. Allow it to sit for several minutes. Scrub the grout with a narrow scrub brush or toothbrush. Rinse completely with warm water. [15] X Research source Try repeating this several times. Baking soda is abrasive, so keep it off the tile as much as possible.

steps.title: Use a steam cleaner.
steps.content: Use a steam cleaner. Choose a machine with high heat and a brush attachment. [16] X Research source Don’t use a machine with a beater bar, which can damage tile. You may want to check if your brand of tile is compatible with using a steam cleaner first. [17] X Research source For example, steam cleaners are not recommended for ceramic tile. [18] X Trustworthy Source US National Park Service Agency responsible for the maintenance and promotion of national parks and monuments Go to source

steps.title: Strip and reseal the caulk.
steps.content: Strip and reseal the caulk. If all else fails, use a sharp-edged tool to scrape away the caulk. Clean the area with a solution of three parts water to one part bleach, and let it dry. Use mildew-resistant caulk to discourage future mold. Make sure to seal the grout correctly so that organic growth won’t re-enter. [19] X Research source If you think the mold may have gotten underneath tiling or otherwise penetrated the structure of the room, you may want to renovate and re-tile the area.

steps.title: Cut down on moisture.
steps.content: Cut down on moisture. Keep a door or window open when you’re showering. Alternately, run a dehumidifier or portable fan after showering. If you have a vent fan, run it before, during, and after your shower. [20] X Research source For example, turn on your vent fan before a morning shower, and keep it running until you leave for the day. Even when the mirror is no longer foggy, there can still be moisture in the air. Mold and mildew thrive where it’s warm, airless and damp.

steps.title: Wipe tiles and grout after showering or cooking.
steps.content: Wipe tiles and grout after showering or cooking. Dry wet grout thoroughly after using moisture in the kitchen or bathroom. Keep a squeegee in the bathroom and squeegee the walls and floor after showering. [21] X Research source Using a squeegee after showering will cut down on surface buildup.

steps.title: Spray diluted tea tree oil regularly as a mold preventative.
steps.content: Spray diluted tea tree oil regularly as a mold preventative. Add ten drops of tea tree oil to a clean spray bottle filled with water. Keep the spray bottle in the bathroom and use the “mist” setting to spray tiles and grout after showering. [22] X Research source You should perform this on a small test area first to make sure there is no negative effect.

steps.title: Keep nearby fabrics dry.
steps.content: Keep nearby fabrics dry. Spread out any wet or damp towels so they can totally dry. For rooms that face a lot of moisture, such as kitchens and bathrooms, opt for synthetic materials, since they hold less moisture. [23] X Research source For example, choose polyester or vinyl for items like bathmats and curtains.

steps.title: Clean routinely to prevent mold.
steps.content: Clean routinely to prevent mold. Spray the grout monthly with an anti-fungal solution. For example, fill a spray bottle with one part water to one part white vinegar. Spray and wipe down the grout. Let the solution dry naturally rather than rinsing it off. If your grout is in a bathroom, clean soap scum weekly.
